Nothoprocta perdicaria, commonly known as the Chilean tinamou, is a species of bird belonging to the tinamou family, Tinamidae. Tinamous are a unique group of South American birds that are distantly related to ratites, such as ostriches and rheas.

The Chilean tinamou is a medium-sized, ground-dwelling bird native to central and southern Chile. It has a compact, rounded body, short wings, and a small, pointed bill. The plumage is predominantly brown with darker barring and markings, providing excellent camouflage in its natural habitat.

This species is known for its elusive and secretive behavior, often remaining hidden in dense vegetation. It feeds primarily on a variety of seeds, insects, and small invertebrates found on the ground. The Chilean tinamou is an important part of the ecosystem, playing a role in seed dispersal and the regulation of insect populations.

Nothoprocta perdicaria is classified as a Least Concern species by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), but it faces some threats from habitat loss and hunting in certain areas. Conservation efforts aim to protect this unique component of the Chilean avifauna.
